title: Israel's Growth and Oppression
shortSummary: Exodus chapter 1 recounts the multiplication of the Israelites in Egypt after Joseph's death and the rise of a new Pharaoh who fears their increasing numbers. This chapter sets the stage for God's deliverance by describing the harsh oppression imposed on Israel, including cruel slavery and the attempted extermination of Hebrew male infants.
timeline: c. 1700-1600 BC - Israel in Egypt before the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Joseph
keyCharacters.description: Son of Jacob who was already in Egypt and had risen to power; his death marks a turning point in Israel's fortunes.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The new king of Egypt who did not know Joseph and feared the growing Israelite population, leading to their oppression.

keyCharacters.name: Shiphrah
keyCharacters.description: One of the Hebrew midwives who feared God and disobeyed Pharaoh's command to kill Hebrew male infants.

keyCharacters.name: Puah
keyCharacters.description: The other Hebrew midwife who, along with Shiphrah, preserved the lives of Hebrew boys by defying Pharaoh's orders.

definitions.definition: Egyptian overseers appointed to enforce hard labor and affliction upon the Israelites.
Women who assisted in childbirth, playing a critical role in the survival of Hebrew infants.
A mixture of mud and straw used in brick-making, symbolizing the harsh labor imposed on Israel.
Fortified store cities built by the Israelites for Pharaoh, representing their forced labor and exploitation.

outline.heading: The Families of Israel Settling in Egypt
outline.description: This section lists the twelve sons of Jacob who came to Egypt and notes the total number of Israelites, emphasizing God's faithfulness in preserving the family line.

outline.heading: Death of Joseph and Israel's Prosperity
outline.description: Joseph and his generation die, but the Israelites continue to multiply greatly, filling the land, which highlights God's blessing despite changing circumstances.

outline.heading: The New Pharaoh’s Fear and Oppression
outline.description: A new king who does not know Joseph fears Israel's growth and subjects them to harsh slavery and forced labor to suppress them.

outline.heading: Pharaoh’s Command to the Midwives
outline.description: Pharaoh orders the Hebrew midwives to kill male infants, but they fear God and disobey, resulting in God's blessing upon them and Israel’s continued growth.

outline.heading: Pharaoh’s Decree to Cast Sons into the River
outline.description: Pharaoh escalates his oppression by commanding all Hebrew male infants to be thrown into the Nile, setting the stage for God's miraculous deliverance.

application: Trust in God's providence even when circumstances seem dire, as He preserves His people through trials.
Obey God’s commands above human orders, especially when they conflict with His moral law, as demonstrated by the midwives.
Recognize the power of faithful courage and integrity in the face of oppression and injustice.
Be encouraged that God blesses those who fear Him and honors their faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: And the children of Israel were fruitful, and increased abundantly, and multiplied, and waxed exceeding mighty; and the land was filled with them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's blessing on Israel's growth despite adverse circumstances.

keyVerses.text: But the midwives feared God, and did not as the king of Egypt commanded them, but saved the men children alive.
keyVerses.significance: It shows the courage and faith of the midwives who obeyed God rather than Pharaoh.

keyVerses.text: And Pharaoh charged all his people, saying, Every son that is born ye shall cast into the river, and every daughter ye shall save alive.
keyVerses.significance: This decree marks the intensification of Israel's persecution and sets the stage for God's deliverance through Moses.
